The dimensions are 2 units in length, 1 unit in width, and 0.5 units in height. The side is curved, and the top and bottom are flat. The part is centered in the image. 1. **Create a new coordinate system:** Define a new coordinate system with the following properties: - Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] - Translation Vector: [0.0, 0.75, 0.0] 2. **Draw the 2D Sketch:** Create a new 2D sketch on the X-Y plane of the defined coordinate system. 3. **Create the first face of the prism:** Draw a polyline with the following lines: - Line 1: Start Point [0.0, 0.119], End Point [0.0687, 0.0] - Line 2: Start Point [0.0687, 0.0], End Point [0.2062, 0.0] - Line 3: Start Point [0.2062, 0.0], End Point [0.2749, 0.119] - Line 4: Start Point [0.2749, 0.119], End Point [0.2062, 0.2381] - Line 5: Start Point [0.2062, 0.2381], End Point [0.0687, 0.2381] - Line 6: Start Point [0.0687, 0.2381], End Point [0.0, 0.119] 4. **Scale the 2D Sketch:** Scale the 2D sketch by a factor of 0.2749. 5. **Transform the Sketch into 3D:** Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the rotation angles and translation vector from the defined coordinate system. 6. **Extrude the 3D Model:** Extrude the 3D face along the Z-axis to a depth of 0.75 units with no offset. The scaling factor is the same as the one used in the sketch scaling step. 7. **Complete the Part:** Finalize the operation by connecting the new extruded volume to the existing CAD body as a new solid body.</description>

prompt: <description>**Part 1 Instructions:** Construct a cylindrical object with a rectangular base and a tapered top. The cylinder is centered on the rectangular base. The top of the cylinder is slightly wider than the base. The height of the cylinder is approximately three times the width of the base. The object is symmetrical along its vertical axis. **Step 1: Create a coordinate system** Begin by creating a new coordinate system. Set the Euler angles to 0.0, 0.0, and -90.0 degrees for the X, Y, and Z axes, respectively. This will create a coordinate system aligned with the rectangular base of the cylindrical object. Next, set the translation vector to [0.0, 0.75, 0.0] for the Y, X, and Z coordinates, respectively. This will position the coordinate system at the center of the base and 0.75 units above the XZ plane. **Step 2: Draw the 2D sketch for the base** Using the created coordinate system, draw a 2D sketch on a plane perpendicular to the Z-axis. This sketch will represent the rectangular base of the cylindrical object. **Step 3: Add a circle to the base** On this 2D sketch, add a circle centered at the point [0.03, 0.03] with a radius of 0.03 units. This circle represents the hole on the base of the cylindrical object. **Step 4: Scale the 2D sketch** Scale the 2D sketch with a scaling factor of 0.06. This will ensure the base has the correct width and height. **Step 5: Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch** Use the euler angles and translation vector provided in the coordinate_system to transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch. **Step 6: Extrude the 2D sketch to create a 3D model** Extrude the 2D sketch with a depth of 0.75 units along the Z-axis. The cylindrical object should now have a height approximately equal to three times its width. **Step 7: Perform a NewBodyFeatureOperation** This completion of this part replaces any preceding CAD models in the assembly with the new cylindrical object. After completing these steps, you should have successfully generated the parametric CAD model as specified in the CAD assembly JSON. Double-check all the dimensions and constraints for accuracy. **Part 1 Dimensions:** * Cylinder width: 0.75 units * Cylinder height: ~2.25 units * Hole diameter: 0.06 units</description>
